learning_outcomes.description: Use Mendelian theories to describe gene inheritance and the relationship with phenotypic expression in animal breeding
Use population information to determine gene frequency and genotypic frequency and explain how these changes impact on genetic change
Describe and calculate the connections between heritability, intensity of selection, accuracy of selection and generation interval on genetic progress in animal breeding programs
Use knowledge about animal breeding programs to evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of selection strategies
Discuss the ethics of animal breeding including impacts of selection and perceptions of advanced gene technologies

assessments.weighting: <dd>15% Each sequential item contributes 5% towards the sequential quizzes (total 15%) </dd>
assessments.due_date:
Quiz 1. Mendel 16/03/2026 - 17/03/2026

Quiz 2. Breeding Objective, Inbreeding and Heritability 27/04/2026 - 28/04/2026

Quiz 3. Heterosis and Hybrid Vigour 25/05/2026 - 26/05/2026

Sequential Quiz will be open for 28 hours. Each sequential quiz will open on the following Monday at 0800 h and close at 1200 h on the Tuesday.
assessments.task_description:
General Information

Students will complete a series of sequential tutorial quizzes throughout the semester. These quizzes include multiple-choice questions focused on problem-solving, as well as short-response questions that require critical thinking and analysis to determine the correct answers. Each quiz will be open for a 28-hour period, during which students must complete it. Each sequential quiz will open on the following Monday at 0800 h and close at 1200 h on the Tuesday. 

In total there are three (3) sequential quizzes that you will be submitting for assessment - each one will be worth 5%, thus contributing 15% of your overall grade for ANIM3046. Quizzes must be undertaken and submitted via the correct link provided on BlackBoard.

Quiz 1. This quiz will cover content from Tutorial 2 Mendelian inheritance. You will be provided with five (5) questions from a pool of questions related to content provided during Tutorial 2. Please note that the questions will come from a question pool and will be randomly generated for each student. The question pool will not be made available to you, however Tutorial 2 is designed to prepare you to undertake this Sequential Quiz.

Quiz 2. This quiz will cover content from Tutorial 4 The Breeding Objective, Inbreeding and Heritability. You will be provided with five (5) questions from a pool of questions related to content provided during Tutorial 4. Please note that the questions will come from a question pool and will be randomly generated for each student. The question pool will not be made available to you, however Tutorial 4 is designed to prepare you to undertake this Sequential Quiz.

Quiz 3. This quiz will cover content from Tutorial 7 Heterosis and Hybrid Vigour. You will be provided with five (5) questions from a pool of questions related to content provided during Tutorial 7. Please note that the questions will come from a question pool and will be randomly generated for each student. The question pool will not be made available to you, however Tutorial 7 is designed to prepare you to undertake this Sequential Quiz.


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in BlackBoard course site for specific instructions. 


Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online test/quiz. 

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Contact AskUs immediately: support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Quizzes must be undertaken and submitted via the correct link available on the course BlackBoard site. First attempt at the quiz will be the grade you are awarded.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Background. The purpose of this assessment is to challenge students to design a fit for purpose breeding program. Breeding Programs are foundational to the management of animal populations and have relevance across companion and production animals as well as wildlife species. Breeding programs are often targeted towards enhancing phenotypic traits, something particularly emphasised in companion animals


For this task you are to design a breeding program based on a scenario and species of your choice. Your assignment is to develop a ten-year breeding program based upon your breeding objective. You will provide a comprehensive report detailing the following:

  1. Population Brief
  2. Breeding Objective
  3. Traits of Importance
  4. Trait Management
  5. Breeding Management
  6. Evaluation of Success
  7. Ten-year Progress Prediction


General Formatting and Communication

Task Size – There is no set limit for this, however a maximum of 3500 words will be applied.

What this means is the entirety of your assessment will not exceed 3500 words, this includes your in-text citations BUT excludes the reference list provided at the end.

Some of you will ask if there is a margin on the word count, yes there is, our general rule is ± 10%, however in this instance I am going to put the hard line on 3500 words. If your submission is above this threshold, your work will be graded to 3500 words and surplus content beyond this will not be considered for your grade.

Referencing style

I am requesting the use of Journal of Animal Science formatting. The reason is simple; in my opinion this is the most simplistic and discipline relevant citation style that exists for us. However, I don’t get too hung up on this, as long as you are consistent with your approach and it's not a numbered format, we will be okay.

General Formatting

Your assessment must be typed, 1.5-to-2.0-line spacings are okay, font size 12, in Australian (British) English and neatly presented. But again, consistency is the key, I don’t get too hung up on this unless there is an inconsistent approach then you will find a comment from me on your submission. So, think of these as general guidelines. Communicating your thoughts in a concise and grammatically correct manner is essential to any written document, here at The University of Queensland or outside this institution, please take care in the preparation of your assessment. 

Credibility & References

You will need to do some reading of the scientific literature, so you are encouraged to choose a topic, well at least a species, that is of interest to you. Selecting a topic that is of interest to you will make this task more enjoyable to complete, otherwise you will find it a dreadful task that you will take nothing away from. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT)

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged (in the form of an AI declaration) appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in BlackBoard course site for specific instructions.


A more comprehensive guideline and grading rubric will be provided to you on BlackBoard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The exam will cover all aspects of the course: Lectures, tutorials, assignment and set readings. The exam will be a two-hour written examination with problem solving and short answer questions and will be similar in format to previous years.

The exam will be an in-person exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.  

Students enrolled in External delivery must attend the exam in-person, either on campus OR at an approved off-campus venue as organized with UQ Examinations. Students who live within a 200km radius of the campus will be expected to attend campus for the exam.  

Examinations will contact students directly to confirm arrangements. Please ensure to check your UQ student email account regularly throughout semester as One reminder will be sent and students who fail to nominate an exam centre and will be automatically assigned to sit their exam on campus. Late nominations will not be accepted. 

Please ensure you update your semester address in Si-net at the start of the semester to accurately reflect where you are residing. 

Permitted Materials 

This examination is a Closed Book Examination where consideration for Specified Materials has been permitted. For this examination you are allowed to take an unmarked bilingual dictionary as the other specified allowed materials and you will require the use of a calculator. 

Calculators

Except for the Casio fx-82 series, all calculators used in an exam must now have an ‘Approved’ label attached. The Approved calculators’ list can be found at – https://my.uq.edu.au/services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/sitting-exam/approved-calculators Your options are: (i) Buy a Casio fx-82 series calculator, which does not require a label, or (ii) Take your calculator to the Student Centre for an approval sticker. To find out more visit: http://www.uq.edu.au/myadvisor/exam-calculators

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1. Introduction animal breeding and genetics | Dr Angela Lees

An introduction to animal breeding and genetics. An introduction to Animal Breeding and Breeding Objectives will be covered.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 1. Introduction animal breeding and genetics | Dr Angela Lees
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1. Introduction animal breeding and genetics | Dr Angela Lees An introduction to animal breeding and genetics. An introduction to Animal Breeding and Breeding Objectives will be covered.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2. Domestication | Dr Angela Lees

We will consider the ethics behind animal breeding and start thinking about how we define breeds and how breeds have been established via domestication. We will start to look at species and approaches to define species.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 2. Domestication | Dr Angela Lees
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2. Domestication  | Dr Angela Lees We will consider the ethics behind animal breeding and start thinking about how we define breeds and how breeds have been established via domestication. We will start to look at species and approaches to define species.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2. Tutorial 1. Systems Analysis | Dr Angela Lees

An introduction to understanding and evaluating systems for animal breeding. At the completion of this activity students will be able to understand breeding goals and evaluating 'best' animals within populations.

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2. Tutorial 1. Systems Analysis  | Dr Angela Lees An introduction to understanding and evaluating systems for animal breeding. At the completion of this activity students will be able to understand breeding goals and evaluating 'best' animals within populations.

A look into Genetic Diversity.

learning_activities.topic:

An introduction to Mendelian Inheritance. At the completion of this activity students will be able to use Mendelian theory to determine gene inheritance and phenotypic expression.

Week 4. Gene inheritance | Dr Angela Lees

Discussing Mendelian genetics, variations to Mendelian Inheritance and inheritance of sex-linked traits.

Using the Hardy Weinberg Equation and its use in determining gene and genotypic frequency in populations.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5. Genes, Heritability and trait importance | Dr Angela Lees

Developing understanding about genes and genomes. The heritability of traits and how that influences traits. Discussions around what traits are important.

A look into Genome Structure & Variation, a refresher on Gene Transcription & Gene Expression. A gentle reminder that there will be no lecture on the Friday as it is Good Friday.
